title: 105_s1794
content: The Act may be cited as the "Gulf War Veterans' Iraqi Claims Protection Act of 1998". Adjudication of claims is addressed in the Act. The United States Commission is authorized to receive and determine claims by U.S. nationals against Iraq, applying applicable law and principles of justice. Priority is given to non-commercial claims before others are decided. The United States Commission decides non-commercial claims of active, retired, or reserve members of the US Armed Forces and other individuals related to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait or the 1987 USS Stark attack. The International Claims Settlement Act applies to these claims. SEC. 3. CLAIMS FUNDS. The Secretary of the Treasury can establish the Iraq Claims Fund for paying claims under section 2(a). Proceeds from Iraqi asset liquidation will be allocated by the President between the Iraq Claims Fund and other appropriate accounts. Iraq Claims Fund is established for paying claims of the United States Government, with a limitation on the amount allocated. The term "certified claims of the United States Government" is defined in this context. The term "certified claims of the United States Government" refers to claims determined by the Secretary of State to be valid and outside the jurisdiction of the United Nations Commission, with a certified amount established under procedures set by the President. The President is authorized to vest and liquidate Iraqi assets in the US to satisfy claims under section 2(a) and claims of the US Government against Iraq. Reimbursement for administrative expenses is also provided. SEC. 5. REIMBURSEMENT FOR ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES. The Secretary of the Treasury deducts 1.5 percent of funds into the Iraq Claims Fund for administrative expenses. Amounts deducted are deposited as miscellaneous receipts in the Treasury of the United States. SEC. 6. PAYMENTS. The United States Commission certifies awards to the Secretary of the Treasury for payment from the Iraq Claims Fund in order of priority. Payment includes $10,000 or the award's principal amount, additional $90,000 for certain claims, and periodic payments towards unpaid balances. After certifying awards, payments are made from the Iraq Claims Fund in order of priority. The unpaid balance of principal amounts is distributed proportionally, followed by pro rata payments for accrued interest. Any remaining funds are transferred to the general fund of the Treasury of the United States. Payment of awards under this Act does not eliminate any unsatisfied claims or rights against the Government of Iraq. The Executive agency can transfer records to the United States Commission for claims adjudication. The Act also includes provisions on the statute of limitations and the disposition of unused funds. The Act includes provisions on the statute of limitations for certified awards. Any demand for payment shall be barred one year after the publication of a notice in the Federal Register, detailing unpaid claims. The Secretary of the Treasury shall dispose of unused funds in the Iraq Claims Fund 2 years after publication of a notice. Unused funds will be deposited into the Treasury if not used for additional payments. The remaining balance in the Iraq Claims Fund will be disposed of by the Secretary of the Treasury if not used for additional payments. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, definitions include terms such as "Executive agency," "Government of Iraq," "United Nations Commission," and "United States Commission." The term "United States Commission" refers to the Foreign Claims Settlement Commission of the United States.
